Reason is based upon ideas that are said to be true only because ideas contrary to them are beyond human comprehension. For example - reason mandates that something can not be and not be in the same place at the same time (A & -A can not be true). There is no further reason to say that this is nessisarly the case though, exsept that one can not fathom the contrary. However, it is necessary that things exist that are beyond human comprehention. The size of the universe, for example: If it is infinite then my finite mind can not fathom what it contains. On the other hand, if it is Finite in size, then I can not comprehend the nothingness beyond it either, how could it exist in no space? What would its shape be if there is no outside to look at it from? or if it is some third opotion that is neither fininte nor infinite - how could that be?
 
 how do you folks who are so keen on your absolute "logic" and "reason" deal with this dilema?

Ripskar

Once you have eliminated the impossible, whatever is left, however improbable, must be the truth.
 Science tends to show that the Universe is finite.
 If the Universe were infinate we would probably not exist.
 Anything beyond the bounds of the Universe is not tied by the restrictions of our Universe and therefore very difficult to fathom.
 eg. Socratic Cause and Effect is reliant on linear time. Time is a facet of our Universe but may not be outside our universe and not at the Big Bang where you see the infinate collapse of 3+K SpaceTime.
 A doorway in our Universe would have a door which would be open or closed, and people could only go through one at a time.
 Under infinate collapse of time the door is both open and closed simultaneously and everyone who goes through the door in its existance does so simultaneously. You may even meet yourself travelling in the opposite direction.
 You can probably only cope with 3 spatial dimensions (length, width and depth) though String Theory suggests many more dimensions, (26) which can only be simulated in a computer hyperspace.

 from your previous post you mentioned that from earth we can observe up to 14.5 billion light years in every direction. i think we can safely assume that the universe is bigger than what we observe, and that we are not in the center of the universe.
 
 based on the big bang theory, the universe must be finite, since it has been expanding at a finite speed for a finite amount of time. however theres a similar theory that says the big bang caused the universe to erupt into being from an infinite number of points, creating a seamless infinite volume, which is also expanding at a finite rate for a finite amount of time.
 
 if you subscribe to the big bang theory to begin with, then you must come to grips with the idea of infinite nothingness that our universe sits in and expands into. fathoming what is beyond the bounds of the universe is a prerequisite of the big bang theory.

Ripskar

The universe is NOT spherical.

 
 The Big Bang is the rapid increase in volume of the Universe, the shape which contains most volume for it's surface is a sphere, which is why bubbles, stars etc. are round. Logically this would be the most likely shape, if we wanted to be more accurate theoretically we could analyse the background microwave radition in the manner of radar to give the precise shape of the edge of the Universe.
 What you seem to suggest is that what lies behind the next hill is beyond human understanding, because noone has yet walked round it.

 Before we go on we need to understand that is not going to make sense intuitively and your not going to be able to picture in your mind what it looks like.
 
 Things exist all around you that don't fit the rules that you're used to.
 
 The next thing we will need to come to grips with is the Cosmological Principle.
 
 The Cosmological Principle states that:
 
 The Universe is homogeneous i.e. there is no preferred location.
 
 The Universe is isotropic i.e. there is no preferred direction.

 According to Dictionary.com, the definition of incomprehensible is:
 
 in·com·pre·hen·si·ble (adj.) 
 A.)Difficult or impossible to understand or comprehend; unintelligible
 B.)Impossible to know or fathom
 
 If something is impossible to understand or comprehend or impossible to know or fathom, clearly we wouldn't know if the idea in question is possible or not. Once again, it seems we have a matter of definition. So, by this regard, I agree with your first point. However, I don't think your second point is true. Logic cannot depend on the idea that the incomprehensible is not possible because we cannot fathom anything that is incomprehensible. Additionally, I don't believe the two ideas are in any way related. It is impossible to apply logic or knowledge while also having to consider anything incomprehensible. For example, we can look at water and know that the elements that make it up are hydrogen and oxygen. We can further discover the exact makeup of water is H2O; 2 hydrogen molecules for every 1 oxygen molecule. As humans, we know and fathom this. We also know that any other makeup of any other molecules or even different ratios of the same molecules will result in another substance. Therefore, I don't think logic can even be related to anything that is incomprehensible, simply because of the nature of incomprehensibility.

GodIsDead

Kant was a 17th century philosopher who was incredibly important and influential. 
 
 You are probably familiar with Descartes' Cogito: I think therefore I am. This was the result of a system of doubt indented to find an absolutely true basis from witch to build an understanding of the world. That came from the second of six "mediations" in Descartes important work "Meditations on first philosophy." In the first meditation he doubted everything he could, based on the idea that his senses could be deceiving him, or that an evil god could be tricking him. The Cogito was all that was left, all he could know was that he existed. You don't here much about the rest of the meditations, because he was not entirely rational about how he went about reconstructing the world beyond himself. What he did was Define god into existence, similarly to the way St. Anselm did, by asserting that Gods own definition necessitates his existence. This is circular and doesn't make any sense, and then furthermore he asserted that god is good by definition, and that therefore there couldn't be an evil god tricking him.
 
 Later on, a philosopher named Hume didn't buy the last few meditations, as many didn't, and sought out to doubt the world in a more complete and rational manner. What Hume came up with in the end was that the only things that could be known were sense perceptions in the moment that they were experienced. Claiming that even things believed to be as certain as cause and effect were only assumptions made based on their persistence. This means that, for example, just because every time in the past that I have walked out my front door I have ended up outside, that doesn't necessarily mean that next time I walk out my front door I wont find myself back inside. Consequently, Hume abandoned philosophy, and took up history instead.
 
 Following Hume was Kant, who, recognizing that this idea reveled the necessary separation of the human mind from reality - sought out to recognize what the relationship between the mind and reality was. Prior to Kant philosophy had been about absolute objective truth, witch Socrates had died for. Kant recognized that we don't have any objective connection to reality, all we have is our own subjective perception of reality. Kant divided the world into two parts the "Phenomenal world" and the "Nominal world" where the Nominal world was the world in itself (witch may or may not exist) and the Phenomenal world was the world we know.
 
 Given that idea, things that are incomprehensible would necessarily be part of the "Nominal world" and, as you point out, DrNo, reason can only be applied to the "Phenomenal world" as reason is within our own mind.
 
 This is an important realization - and it is the reason I asked this question. It is a common mistake for people to talk about reason as though it is something absolute and objective, when in reality it is merely a system that is applied to subjective perceptions. When two people have contradicting points of view on something - whether conception Is the beginning of life or not, for example - its often essentially because their intuitive subjective perception Is just different. Consequently, it feels plain and obvious to both sides, and so to appeal to the authority of Logic at this point is by claiming that your side is just more logical is to equate logical with obvious. And that doesn't make sense, because the obvious can vary from person to person
DrNo

This is an important realization - and it is the reason I asked this question. It is a common mistake for people to talk about reason as though it is something absolute and objective, when in reality it is merely a system that is applied to subjective perceptions. When two people have contradicting points of view on something - whether conception Is the beginning of life or not, for example - its often essentially because their intuitive subjective perception Is just different. Consequently, it feels plain and obvious to both sides, and so to appeal to the authority of Logic at this point is by claiming that your side is just more logical is to equate logical with obvious. And that doesn't make sense, because the obvious can vary from person to person

 
 And yet, even if we cannot change what is obvious to a person, the exchange of ideas between people has spurred creative inventions and scientific breakthroughs throughout history.

http://mensa.ast.uct.ac.za/research/ga.html
 The methodology which I used to generate the figure in the above post contains innaccuracies, (effect of Dark Energy, Gravitational distortion of the Great Attractor and the difference in velocities between the motion of the Virgo Supercluster and the motion of the Milky Way.)
 However it does produce a ball park figure.
 If I were to do it properly I would use the methodolgy described in the Mensa site, which located the Great Attractor in the first place.
 
The recession velocities of relatively nearby galaxies show systematic deviations from a uniform expansion field.

 Due to the nature of the Virgo Supercluster being our own I would use the recessional velocities of other superclusters at greater distance.
 The Theory of the Cosmological Principle would appear to be at odds with observations of the Virgo Supercluster. Not everything is receding, several galaxies have blue shift. That the Principal only applies at the largest scale is telling, it doesn't actually have observational data to back it up.
 Indeed the Background Microwave Radiation must have bounced off something, indicating an edge to the Universe.
 The Galaxies shown in the Hubble Deep Field Scan are receeding at 0.9c, as it is impossible for anything to travel at <1c it would appear that we are looking at the limits of what is possible.
 All these observations post-date the writing of the Cosmological Principal.
